item.title: Nigeria reopens cities as lockdown eases
item.description: Nigeria has begun easing restrictions in its capital Abuja and in Lagos, its largest city, marking the reopening of Africa's biggest economy after more than four weeks of lockdown.

item.title: China rejects US virus allegations
item.description: Chinese state media have hit back at the US, accusing President Donald Trump's administration of trying to distract from its own "incompetence" with allegations about the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Spain’s COVID-19 death toll climbs by 164
item.description: Spain's death toll from the coronavirus epidemic has risen by 164.

item.title: Haircuts, flowers as Greek lockdown eases
item.description: Greek hair salons, flower shops and bookstores have reopened as part of a gradual easing of lockdown restrictions imposed six weeks ago to curb the spread of the new coronavirus.

item.title: Five dead in Taliban’s Afghan bomb attack
item.description: The Taliban has claimed responsibility for a truck bomb in southern Helmand province which has killed at least five Afghan security force members, adding to weeks of rising violence in the country.

item.title: South Korean students going back to school
item.description: South Korea says it will reopen schools in stages starting from May 13, as the daily number of domestic cases of the new coronavirus has fallen close to zero over recent days.

item.title: Russia coronavirus cases pass 10,000 again
item.description: The number of coronavirus cases in Russia has risen by more than 10,000 again over the past 24 hours with 76 new deaths.

item.title: Pledging ‘marathon’ for vaccine research
item.description: World leaders are holding an international pledging "marathon" to raise at least 7.5 billion euros ($A12.8 billion) for research into a possible vaccine and treatments for the coronavirus, after rich countries promised a unified response.

item.title: NSW return-to-school plans vary
item.description: The NSW government wants schools to resume face-to-face classes from next week - generally one day a week at first - but the Catholic and independent sectors are working to resume full-time teaching faster than that.

item.title: China has COVID-19 questions to answer: UK
item.description: Britain's defence minister says China has questions to answer over the information it had shared about the coronavirus outbreak but a post mortem examination over its role should come later, Britain's defence minister said.
